Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Planning Reliable and Resilient Transportation Networks against Correlated Infrastructure Disruptions

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative research project aims to discover a methodological framework that enhances the reliability and resilience of transportation network infrastructure systems that are exposed to multiple linked disruption risks. Such linked risks could be caused by exposure to common hazards or shared unreliable supplies. We will first establish a decomposition theory that transforms a general infrastructure system with linked facility disruption risks into one with a simpler and more explicit structure with only independent disruptions, yet ensuring that the two systems have exactly equivalent functionalities and operational behaviors. Based on this theoretical foundation, a set of advanced mathematical models will be created to address a number of pressing engineering challenges, including (i) reliable network design, (ii) critical infrastructure protection, and (iii) cascading failure mitigation. Case studies from real-world infrastructure systems (e.g., bridge networks exposed to earthquakes, electricity grids experiencing power plant disruptions) will be used to validate the theory and illustrate the practical applicability of these models.

If successful, the results of this research will (i) advance the knowledge base needed to address a wide range of infrastructure disruptions in many engineering contexts, (ii) provide managerial insights that hold the promise of enhancing the reliability and resilience of various infrastructure systems. This will have impacts not only on transportation and manufacturing industries but also on social communities. This project will also result in new educational practices by the integration of the research into educational materials and activities, including a new role-playing game for interactive teaching focused on infrastructure disruption mechanisms and protection strategies. Collaborations with public agencies (e.g. state Departments of Transportation) and private freight and manufacturing industries (e.g. CSX Transportation Inc. and Caterpillar Inc.) will help assure that the research and educational activities are of practical relevance and importance, and that the outcomes are readily implementable.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This collaborative research project aims to discover a methodological framework that enhances the reliability and resilience of transportation network infrastructure systems that are exposed to multiple linked disruption risks. Such linked risks could be caused by exposure to common hazards or shared unreliable supplies. We have propose a new methodology framework for analyzing and modeling facility disruptions with general correlations. The proposed framework examines the commonalities from seemingly-unrelated infrastructure systems and proposes a unified framework to characterize interdependences and structured interactions among infrastructure facilities. The proposed correlation decomposition scheme provides an innovative way to represent an interdependent infrastructure network under generally correlated disruptions. The equivalent network representation contains only simple independent disruptions and, for the first time, enables us to quantify the performance of this network in a compact-sized (i.e., of low-order polynomial to the network size) expression with a high-fidelity approximation. This scheme avoids enumerating an extremely large number (i.e., exponential to the network size) of disruption scenarios, and it opens up tremendous opportunities to transform a set of traditionally hard problems in the field of transportation infrastructure systems into compact solvable models. It enables modeling developments for solving a range of traditional hard network design models with element correlation or interdependence in various engineering contexts. With this, we proposed optimization models to solve optimal system design for a number of engineering systems, including supply chains, transportation infrastructure, power grids, disaster evacuation, traffic sensor, bio fuel systems. The analysis of system interdependence even sheds light on modeling and optimizing connected & autonomous vehicle systems. We have published a number of high-caliber academic articles, including 14 journal publications in peer-reviewed journals (most of which are top journals in transportation). We have collected a set of disaster data and made educational materials (including course slides and website tools) for undergraduate and graduate students. These materials can be used not only for college education but also for spreading knowledge to K-12 students and the general public. The outcomes from this research have benefited and will continue to benefit stakeholders like state departments of transportations and other transportation agencies.
